dt: {bc}serving to offset or compensate for a defect

dt.t: her performance is the film's {wi}redeeming{/wi} feature

shortdef: serving to offset or compensate for a defect

dt: {bc}to free from what {d_link|distresses|distress:2} or harms: such as
{bc}to free from captivity by payment of {d_link|ransom|ransom:1}
{bc}to {d_link|extricate|extricate} from or help to overcome something {d_link|detrimental|detrimental:1}
{bc}to free from a {d_link|lien|lien} by payment of an amount secured {d_link|thereby|thereby}
{bc}to remove the obligation of by payment

dt.t: the U.S. Treasury {wi}redeems{/wi} savings bonds on demand

pt: {sc}rescue{/sc} {sc}deliver{/sc} {sc}redeem{/sc} {sc}ransom{/sc} {sc}reclaim{/sc} {sc}save{/sc} mean to set free from confinement or danger. {sc}rescue{/sc} implies freeing from imminent danger by prompt or vigorous action.

pt.t: {it}rescued{/it} the crew of a sinking ship

pt: {sc}deliver{/sc} implies release usually of a person from confinement, temptation, slavery, or suffering.
{sc}redeem{/sc} implies releasing from bondage or penalties by giving what is demanded or necessary.

pt.t: job training designed to {it}redeem{/it} school dropouts from chronic unemployment

pt: {sc}ransom{/sc} specifically applies to buying out of captivity.
{sc}reclaim{/sc} suggests a bringing back to a former state or condition of someone or something abandoned or debased.
{sc}save{/sc} may replace any of the foregoing terms; it may further imply a preserving or maintaining for usefulness or continued existence.

quotes.t: Nearly 115 million Americans clip coupons and {qword}redeem{/qword} them at some point during the year.
… nor does the book try to justify whatever is reckless about it by claiming some {qword}redeeming{/qword} social or political value.
Their temporal dominion is now confirmed by the reverence of a thousand years; and their noblest title is the free choice of a people, whom they had {qword}redeemed{/qword} from slavery.

aq.source: {it}The History of the Decline and Fall of the Roman Empire{/it}

quotes.t: We had, however, {qword}redeemed{/qword} … the character of our country, by showing that there was at any rate a body of persons determined to use all the means which the law afforded to obtain justice for the injured.
She had once told Rowland that she would show him, some day, how gracious her manners could be; she was now {qword}redeeming{/qword} her promise.

et: Middle English {it}redemen{/it}, from Anglo-French {it}redemer{/it}, modification of Latin {it}redimere{/it}, from {it}re-, red-{/it} re- + {it}emere{/it} to take, buy; akin to Lithuanian {it}imti{/it} to take
shortdef: to free from what distresses or harms: such as
